#Text=Boston/South Boston
#Text=Honor .
#Text=Tradition .
#Text=Loyalty .
#Text=If you 're familiar with South Boston as presented on the silver screen , these values might spring foremost to your mind .
#Text=You would n't be wrong , but a lot has changed since mob boss Whitey Bulger controlled his criminal underworld from here during the 1970s .
#Text=The identity of " Southie " , as it 's known to locals , is being reshaped .

column1: #Text=Understand
#Text=Originally , South Boston was known as " Dorchester Neck " , a small isthmus in northern Dorchester .
#Text=Once all but disconnected from downtown , acres of land were created throughout the 19th century physically bringing the two towns together .
#Text=This was a burgeoning area for maritime industries , and was first annexed by Boston in 1804 , and then again in 1870 .
#Text=Southie really distinguished itself with the arrival of the Irish after the Great Famine in the mid 19th century .
#Text=The quintessential triple decker homes and their occupants of Irish decent remain .
#Text=Neighbors still greet one another on the street as they go about their daily routines .
#Text=But things are different now .
#Text=Money abounds in this area so close to downtown Boston .
#Text=Real estate developers make million dollar offers to long time residents , sight unseen .
#Text=What does it matter what the insides look like when you 'll be tearing the whole thing down anyway .
#Text=These trends will continue into the foreseeable future , as more of Southie has been rezoned to resemble the Seaport .
#Text=In spite of these challenges , pockets of the old-time community spirit persist .
#Text=Some shops and restaurants have remained popular with new residents .
#Text=The St. Patrick 's Day Parade continues each year .
#Text=The Neighborhood character evolves as ideas from newcomers mix with the best from the old guard .
#Text=Neighborhoods
#Text=The Seaport :
#Text=No other neighborhood in Boston ( and few in America ) have undergone so much change in so little time .
#Text=Back in 2004 , the area was nothing more than acres of windswept parking lots .
#Text=By 2014 those lots had been replaced by a convention center , an art gallery , scores of office and residential towers , and a mass transit system .
#Text=Over a trillion dollars ( yes with a t ! ) of new real estate washed onto the market during that decade , and continues to do so .
#Text=Debate continues about whether the redevelopment of the Seaport is succeeding in turning the area into a real community .
#Text=There are no grocery stores or public schools here yet , but the area and the idea is still new .
#Text=Give it time to see what Boston 's newest incarnation develops .
#Text=Fort Point :
#Text=Nuzzled in below the Seaport , think of Fort Point as its older , smaller brother .
#Text=When the manufacturing industry collapsed , many beautiful brick factories along the channel were simply too big and expensive to tear down .
#Text=What was bad news at the time has turned out great for today 's Bostonians , as many large industrial spaces were preserved and live on today as fantastic hotels and restaurants .
#Text=Just check out the cluster of interesting points around Congress and A streets .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=Red Line stations in the area are Broadway and Andrew .
#Text=JFK/UMass
#Text=station is in neighboring Dorchester , but is very close as well .
#Text=Silver Line bus routes SL1 and SL2 run rapid transit service run between South Station and through the seaport district .
#Text=The Courthouse , World Trade Center , and Silver Line Way stations are served by both routes .
#Text=The SL2 route continues its loop through South Boston stopping at Harbor St , Tide St , 23 Dry Dock Ave , 88 Black Falcon Ave , and Design Center .
#Text=While the SL1 branch veers off and heads away to Logan airport .
#Text=For those trying to get deeper into South Boston , you 'll need to ride the bus .
#Text=Routes #5 , #7 , #9 , #10 , and #11 all start near City Point and connect to Red Line stops : South Station , Broadway , and Andrew .
#Text=It 's hard to overstate the impact of all the construction , and the neighborhood has been welcoming scores of new residents every month for years .
#Text=While the number of commuters increases , the number of busses has not been able to keep pace with the demand .
#Text=Beyond normal rush hour traffic , it can be quite difficult to board busses headed downtown in the morning , and leaving the city at night .
#Text=The MBTA is working on addressing this issue , but for now plan on riding late , crowded busses .
#Text=By boat
#Text=There are actually quite a few services available along the waterfront in Southie .
#Text=One of the most popular and frequent are Water Taxis .
#Text=These little boats run all year round and service points of interest like The Children 's Museum , the ICA , World Trade Center , and more .
#Text=You 'll have to call ahead in less popular locations and times .
#Text=Hop aboard a real ship and take the Bay State Cruise Company 's Provincetown Fast Ferry , running from the pier with the Seaport Hotel during the summer months .
#Text=Additionally , over 20 cruise lines dock their mega ships at Black Falcon Pier .
#Text=During the warmer months they may arrive from ports as far as Europe and the Caribbean .
#Text=Local taxis know these schedules , so you should have no problem transporting yourself and your luggage to the hotel .
#Text=Smaller boats can be found at the EDIC Pier and provide service to and from the Boston Harbor Islands .
#Text=Keep your eyes peeled , because this pier can easily be overlooked .
#Text=It 's right next to the bridge , do n't walk too far down towards the enormous Black Falcon area .
#Text=By car
#Text=Many parking lots have been replaced by luxury condos , so think before you drive , especially in the seaport .
#Text=There is some on street parking in the remaining industrial-feeling areas towards the center of the neighborhood , but much of it is n't any more convenient than walking from a T station .

#Text=Some two way roads were converted to one way during the " snowpocalypse " events of 2015 , so know your GPS directions may be incorrect . Watch for cars coming to a stop in the middle of the road , as some residents feel entitled to double park wherever they please , especially on Broadway .
#Text=Do n't bother trying to find parking out at Castle Island during the summer , but you might luck out if you go at odd times .
#Text=In wintertime you may find " space savers " placed in shoveled out parking spots .
#Text=You are legally allowed to move these items and park , but by doing so you place your vehicle at risk of being vandalized .
#Text=Exit 25 of Interstate 90 and Exit 16 of Interstate 93 serve the area and are found at the extreme western edge .
